reach Euro 2024 knockouts", "body": "Gelsenkirchen (Germany) (AFP) - Spain qualified for the last 16 of Euro 2024 with a match to spare on Thursday after beating Italy 1-0 in a dominant display which ensured that La Roja would go through as Group B winners.\n\nRiccardo Calafiori's own goal nine minutes after half-time was the difference between the two sides at Gelsenkirchen in the biggest match to date at the tournament in Germany.\n\nBut the slender margin of victory didn't reflect a statement performance from Spain who completely nullified Italy and should have had the game won by half-time, as they did in their opening round thumping of Croatia.\n\nNico Williams was the star for Spain as he ran Napoli right-back Giovanni Di Lorenzo ragged and supplied the cross from which the unfortunate Calafiori poked the winning goal into his own net.\n\nLuis de la Fuente's team have a perfect six points at the top of the group and take on Albania on Monday knowing that they are already in the knockout rounds and playing like potential champions.\n\nFor Italy Thursday's deserved defeat was a reality check as vibrant Spain peppered the brilliant Gianliugi Donnarumma's goal throughout the match while the Azzurri failed to have a single attempt on target.\n\nIt was a performance reminiscent of the Euro 2012 final between the two teams when Spain crushed Italy 4-0 in the last international hurrah for tiki-taka football.\n\nHowever all is not lost for Luciano Spalletti's team, who are second on three points, as a draw with Croatia on Monday will be enough to guarantee qualification behind Spain.\n\nWilliams shines for Spain\n\nSpain could have been ahead twice in the first 10 minutes but squandered two great headed chances.\n\nLess than two minutes were on the clock when an unmarked Pedri nodded Williams' pinpoint cross straight at Donnarumma.\n\nAnd then Williams, who had a field day against Di Lorenzo, was the guilty party by somehow heading wide Alvaro Morata's superbly delivered, inswinging ball from the left flank.\n\nSpain were clearly on top as Italy struggled to get out of their half, Gianluca Scamacca toiling on his own up front with little support and wasting possession when it did come his way.\n\nDonnarumma had to be at his best twice within a matter of seconds when he first stuck out a foot to deny Morata and then pulled off a superb fingertip save which kept out Fabian Ruiz's powerful drive from distance.\n\nMeanwhile at the other end of the pitch Spain goalkeeper Unai Simon was a virtual spectator as Italy's sole shot in the first half came just before the break when Federico Chiesa blazed a poor effort over from a difficult position.\n\nThe same pattern of Spanish possession and Italian defending continued after half-time and Pedri again wasted a great chance in the 51st minute, slamming wide after Marc Cucurella pulled back a perfect low cross.\n\nBut Spain got the breakthrough soon after and it came through more sensational play from Williams on the left, who made mincemeat of Di Lorenzo before fizzing across a ball which Calafiori couldn't help but divert into his own goal.\n\nLa Roja went close to doubling their lead with two distance strikes from Morata and teen sensation Lamine Yamal, before the superb Williams smashed an effort past Donnarumma which came crashing out off the crossbar in the 71st minute.\n\nItaly pushed forward in hope of an equaliser after Mattia Zaccagni and Mateo Retegui replaced the ineffective Chiesa and Scamacca.\n\nBut in the dying moments Donnarumma again made two Italy sits in 22nd for counterattack shots allowed, which could lead Alvaro Morata to plenty of scoring chances. Italy could force Spain into more crosses, which Morata can excel at finishing. Crossing the ball isn't Spain's specialty, though, meaning a solid tactical approach by Luciano Spaletti and his staff could slow Spain's attack.\n\nSpain's high-powered offense could prove too overwhelming for Italy. They don't have the best backline, while Spain had 2.51 expected goals per match and 17.8 shots/90 in qualifying.\n\nWhy Italy Will Win\n\nOne of Spain's biggest weaknesses is their defensive center backs, leaving them prone to giving up goals off crosses and long balls. It will play right into Italy's hands, as they prefer to go over the top and use crosses from the flanks.\n\nItaly's defense is also susceptible to this, but they won't have that problem against Spain. Spain uses a possession-based style of play, like the games we see in La Liga. Italy's weakness is that they rank near the bottom in forward pass completion, long-ball completion, and counterattack shots allowed.\n\nFinal Spain-Italy Prediction & Pick\n\nThe scores of these teams' opening games don't tell the full story. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nAs Nico Williams weighed up Giovanni Di Lorenzo in the early moments of the second half on a charged evening in Gelsenkirchen, the Italy defender must have felt as if his night was never going to end. Williams had been everywhere but still had one more trick: Italy had compromised their gameplan in an attempt to finally subdue the thrilling Spain winger, but Williams carried the spirit of this young team and simply went again as he found the avenue to his left. A moment that had been building since kick-off finally arrived as Williams produced the cross that led to Riccardo Calafiori's own goal. By the end, Spain had battered Italy 1-0.\n\nEven as Luis de la Fuente's side sealed their place in the last-16 with a game to spare, Spain deserved more. For the best part of an hour, they tore the holders Italy apart, led by Williams and his evisceration of Di Lorenzo. Spain really should have found the goals to seal a statement victory such a performance had merited, one of fearlessness that was summed up by irrepressible displays from their young winger Williams, and the even younger 16-year-old Lamine Yamal. Italy, who hung on to set up a nervy ending, were far from looking like the champions of three years ago.\n\nIn that, Spain earned some revenge for their semi-final defeat at Euro 2020, while looking like a more complete side from that tournament. La Roja are certainly more exciting and have certainly more than matched Germany with their first two performances. But if the hosts have been carried on by their own sense of momentum, Spain are generating theirs. The fearlessness of Williams and Yamal to run and run, terrorising their full-backs, offers Spain considerable energy as well as skill. Spain were alive and electrified, all over the pitch.\n\nThat includes a magnificently committed performance from Marc Cucurella, the Chelsea defender who looked like he would not make the squad a couple of months ago before his club form turned around. The left-back was excellent against Italy's Federico Chiesa, flying into challenges as if his life depended on it, his mane flowing wildly. It meant Italy, despite their ambition before the game to control possession, couldn't gain a foothold. The commanding Gianluigi Donnarumma kept Italy in it with a series of excellent saves but unlike the Wembley penalty shootout victory over Spain three years ago, he couldn't be the hero.\n\nThe meeting of Spain and Italy for a fifth European Championship in a row and the latest chapter of the most played rivalry of the tournament's history brought the biggest night of Euro 2024 so far. If the group stages of the tournament have been defined by the efforts of the unfancied nations seizing their moment, such a Turkey and Georgia taking swings at each other for 90 minutes in the rain in Dortmund, Spain brought a different level of intensity as they met the holders Italy and wiped them off the park for the best part of an hour.\n\nAll that talk before the game about Italy wanting to control possession and Spain accepting they were more dangerous without the ball? Well, old habits die hard. Spain dominated and, from the very start, it was impossible to look away from Williams. The 21-year-old missed the biggest chance of the first half when he headed wide Alvaro Morata's excellent whipped cross at the back post, but Williams kept on going, finding he had the beating of Di Lorenzo inside and out.\n\nOn the other wing, Yamal drew the first ooos from the crowd with an elegant spin, then had everyone on their feet as he lowered his head, steadied for the contact, and then emerged as if he was floating through the air. A magnificent run fell to the feet of Morara and, from the angle, Donnarumma blocked his shot with his feet. By then, Donnarumma had tipped over Pedri's header, set up by who else but Williams, before he managed to get the slightest touch on a rising strike hit ferociously by Fabian Ruiz.\n\nIt capped a frantic period where Italy couldn't get out and the Spain breakthrough felt inevitable. Italy made it to the break having been restricted to one effort on goal and attempted to regroup. Luciano Spalletti made two changes at the break with his ambition up in smoke, bringing off Jorginho and Davide Frattesi, sacrificing control in the middle for numbers on the outside - specifically, the side of Williams.\n\nOn came Andrea Cambiaso and Bryan Cristante, the former positioned ahead of the struggling Di Lorenzo. Cambiaso may have looked at the Spain winger's treatment of Di Lorenzo and run onto the pitch with wobbling legs. In any case, Italy failed to shut down the Spain left. Pedri could only steer wide from Cucurella's cut-back moments after the restart, as Italy retreated further and abandoned Spalletti's principles with a series of alarmed, rushed clearances.\n\nThen, finally, the moment came, and to no one's surprise it was Williams again, flying at Di Lorenzo and Cambiaso and beating them both. The ball was flashed across the face of goal and although Spain were missing a forward presence, Williams found an area where it caused panic: his cross took a deflection before a touch from the diving Donnarumma sent it into the knee of Calafiori. The centre-back, who carries a hapless air alongside occasional brilliance, fell to to the ground as it deflected in.\n\nSpain kept flowing forward and, thrillingly, trying new things. Yamal bent a stunning shot inches wide of the bar post, and then Williams attempted the same, crashing a thunderous hit off the crossbar as if they were in competition with each other.\n\nThe end of the game turned when Yamal and Williams were brought off, with Spain falling back. Italy survived long enough and suddenly felt as if they were going to get a chance, heads lifting like a rising corpse. A Calafiori header flashed wide but nothing else of substance came, even as Donnarruma went up for a late corner.\n\nIt would have been a robbery had Italy nicked something, and in holding out Spain learned something else too. Often, the most watchable exciting team at the tournament does not win it, and are found to be missing something by the latter stages. But Spain, with this new generation, look like they will be going further than many expected. {"uri": "8183531801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:54:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:54:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:53:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://talksport.com/betting/1925338/spain-vs-croatia-euro-odds-2024/", "title": "Spain vs Italy predictions, odds and betting tips", "body": "One of the standout fixtures of the group stage of Euro 2024 will take place on Thursday.\n\nFind the latest match odds for Spain vs Italy prediction. All odds are provided by our best-reviewed football betting sites. Odds are subject to change.\n\nFor a long time, Spain were one of the biggest underachievers in international football. Up until 2008, they had only ever won one major trophy - and their sole success came on home soil at Euro 1964.\n\nAround that time, Spanish football was producing an abundance of small, technically gifted footballers. Luis Aragones, a manager renowned for a direct, physical approach, recognised what he had at his disposal and began the shift towards a possession-based style of play.\n\nIt would prove to be transformative. Spain went on to win three tournaments in a row: Euro 2008, the 2010 World Cup and Euro 2012. Aragones was the manager for the first triumph, with Spain strengthening the gospel of ball-control-at-all-costs under his successor Vicente del Bosque.\n\nEventually, though, the stars of those victories went past their peak and opponents worked out how to stop Spain. In more recent times, la Roja have been pretty disappointing.\n\nOn occasion they have even descended into self-parody, dominating possession but providing little thrust or cutting edge. At Euro 2016, World Cup 2018 and World Cup 2022, Spain went out in the last 16.\n\nIn their first game at this tournament, though, Spain ripped up the playbook. For the first time since the final of Euro 2008, they had a lesser share of possession than their opponents in a competitive match.\n\nCroatia controlled the ball for 54 percent of the time on Saturday, as Spain demonstrated a willingness to go a little more direct. The result? Luis de la Fuente's side ran out 3-0 winners to take control of Group B.\n\nTo be clear, Spain have not suddenly become a route-one, long-ball side. But in Nico Williams, Dani Olmo and Lamine Yamal, they have several players who thrive in one-versus-one situations and prefer to run at their markers rather than turning back and playing a safe horizontal pass.\n\nWhether or not it helps la Roja get any closer to another piece of silverware remains to be seen. But it is certainly an interesting twist on the usual Spanish dish.\n\nThe winner of Spain vs Italy will be in pole position to finish top of Group B at Euro 2024.\n\nItaly also got off to a winning start, beating Albania 2-1 despite falling behind within 23 seconds. It was a decent first performance from the Azzurri, but this will be a much sterner examination of their credentials.\n\nItaly arrived in Germany with low expectations. They will hope that ultimately works in their favour, but Spain will put them through their paces on Thursday.\n\nDe la Fuente's side should ultimately have too much quality for the defending champions. Man for man, the likely Spain XI is superior to Italy's.\n\nA midfield three of Rodri, Fabian Ruiz and Pedri will help Spain to get control in the centre of the park, especially if Italy stick with the 4-2-3-1 formation we saw against Albania.\n\nAnd as the Croatia match revealed, Spain now have the players to quicken the tempo in the final third.\n\nThis is not a vintage Italy team and this could ultimately be a frustrating night for Luciano Spalletti and co.\n\n\u26bd Tip Spain to win at 23/20 with Betfred \u26bd\n\nSpain's 3-0 victory over Croatia may give the impression that it was a one-sided encounter. In fact, Croatia had more shots and a higher xG.\n\nThat does not mean Spain were not worthy winners. But it does point to the fact that they have up a fair few chances on matchday one.\n\nThat is something that will give Italy confidence ahead of this blockbuster clash in Gelsenkirchen.\n\nThey will look to get the likes of David Frattesi, Lorenzo Pellegrini and Federico Chiesa into pockets of space between the lines, from where they will be able to cause the Spanish defence problems.\n\nIn truth, De la Fuente's charges were fortunate to keep a clean sheet in their first game. They might not be so lucky this time around.\n\n\u26bd Select both teams to score at 16/19 with VBET \u26bd\n\nYamal was the most eye-catching performer in Spain's triumph over Croatia at the weekend. His performance was excellent even before you consider he is just 16 years of age.\n\nYamal registered an assist in the 3-0 win, setting up Dani Carvajal's goal with a delicious cross from the right flank.\n\nSpain's coaches at club and international level have a duty of care given the winger's tender years. It would be a great shame if he was overworked as a teenager and burned out too quickly.\n\nBut De la Fuente will find it difficult to leave Yamal out of the XI after his showing last time out.\n\nThe Barcelona boy is fearless and he will give Italy left-back Federico Dimarco plenty to think about in this one.\n\nWhether it is a goal or another assist, expect Yamal to be heavily involved in Spain's attacking output.\n\n\u26bd Back Lamine Yamal to score or assist at 6/4 with Sky Bet \u26bd\n\nCommercial content notice: Taking one of the bookmaker offers featured in this article may result in a payment to talkSPORT. 18+. dispatch subpar Italy to seal last-16 berth at Euro 2024", "body": "Spain put in an impressive display to claim a narrow 1-0 victory over Italy and seal their place in the last 16 at Euro 2024.\n\nyou have updates\n\nSpain booked their spot in the last 16 of Euro 2024 with a much-deserved 1-0 victory over Italy in Gelsenkirchen.\n\nThe second matchday in Group B pitted the reigning European Champions against a Spain side looking to replicate the Euros success of 2008 and 2012.\n\nThe pattern of the contest was established from the off as Spain launched a relentless onslaught to pepper Italy's goal in the opening 25 minutes.\n\nPedri, Nico Williams, Alvaro Morata and Fabian Ruiz all threatened to break the deadlock in a dominant first period, but Italy ultimately stood firm to scrape through to half-time unscathed.\n\nLa Roja showed no signs of letting up, and their constant pressure ultimately told in the 55th minute when Riccardo Calafiori inadvertently sent the ball into his own net.\n\nA second Spain goal appeared more likely than an Italy equaliser, but Luis de la Fuente's young guns had to settle for just a narrow victory which ensures Spain will participate in the knockout rounds of a fifth consecutive European Championships.\n\nWilliams and co pile pressure on Italy\n\nBuoyed from their dominant 3-0 win over Croatia, Spain threatened to take the lead inside the opening two minutes in Gelsenkirchen.\n\nWilliams neatly worked the space to stand the ball up for Pedri to attack, but the midfielder was unable to his head over the ball, giving Gianluigi Donnarumma the chance to tip over the bar.\n\nWilliams then spurned a glorious opportunity, sending his header wide from Alvaro Morata's inch-perfect delivery from the left flank.\n\nAs the contest moved past the 20-minute mark, Morata found himself in more familiar terrority, receiving the ball in the box before taking one touch too many, allowing Donnarumma to close the angle and make a strong near-post stop.\n\nWith Spain unable to convert the conventional chances, Ruiz took it upon himself to unleash a thunderous long-range strike which required another important intervention from Donnarumma.\n\nItaly boss Luciano Spalletti would have been disappointed by the fact his troops failed to register a single shot on target in the first period, but the only saving grace was that the contest remained goalless at the break.\n\nSpain get deserved breakthrough\n\nIn an attempt to turn the tide, Spalleti turned to his bench at the interval, introducing Roma's Bryan Cristante and Juventus' Andrea Cambiaso.\n\nHowever, those changes failed to have the desired effect as Spain continued to open up the Italian defence, with Pedri arriving in the box to meet Marc Cucurella's neat pullback, only to guide the ball harmlessly wide of Donnarumma's goal.\n\nWith Spain unable to take advantage of their clearcut chances, they were ultimately given a massive helping hand when Calafiori diverted the ball into his own net in the 55th minute.\n\nWilliams drove towards the byline before sending a cross which was met Morata, who forced Donnarumma to parry with his left hand, causing the ball to bounce off the unfortunate Calafiori and into the net.\n\nAfter playing a key role in the opener, Williams nearly put his own name on the scoresheet when he cut inside from the left and unleashed a thunderous strike against Donnarumma's crossbar.\n\nSubstitute Ayoze Perez threatened a couple of times in stoppage time, but Spain was unable to grab a deserved second goal.\n\nAs for Italy, they finished the contest with just one shot on target and very rarely looked like finding a way back into the contest.\n\nMan of the Match - Nico Williams\n\nCucurella, Ruiz and Yamal all have claims to be awarded Man of the Match following their contributions in the statement victory.\n\nHowever, Williams probably just edges out his teammates, especially after he sent in the dangerous cross that led to the decisive goal.\n\nThe Athletic Bilbao winger was a constant threat on the left flank and can count himself unlucky that he did not get his name on the scoresheet.\n\nWhat next for Spain and Italy?\n\nHaving secured top spot in Group B, De la Fuente may be tempted to rotate his squad for Monday's clash with Albania.\n\nIn contrast to La Roja, Italy still have work to do after suffering their first defeat since losing to England in October 2023.\n\nThe Azzurri are currently in second place and two points better off than Albania and their final {"uri": "2024-06-394922623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:57:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:57:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:34:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.covers.com/soccer/euro/spain-vs-italy-prediction-picks-6-20-2024", "title": "Spain vs Italy Odds, Picks & Predictions - Euro 2024", "body": "It's a meeting of familiar foes when Spain and Italy meet for the fifth straight European Championship, but the style of play each team brings into this one is vastly different. Find out why our soccer expert belives goals are on the cards on Thursday.\n\nSpain and Italy will seek pole position for Group B of Euro 2024 when these two football powerhouses meet on Thursday.\n\nSpain vanquished Croatia 3-0 to open their campaign with Alvaro Morata once again finding the back of the net. They notched all three goals before halftime and then relied on stout goalkeeping to secure the win.\n\nNow they face off with a familiar foe. Italy have never lost three straight matches to Spain, and are looking for payback after losing consecutive Nations League semi-finals to the Iberian side. They'll be bolstered by their comeback 2-1 win over Albania after an embarrassing start, and the fact they've lost just once to Spain in 10 meetings in the Euros or World Cup.\n\nFind out where my Euro 2024 picks lie in my Spain vs Italy prediction for their Euro 2024 fixture on June 20, 2024.\n\nSpain vs Italy picks, predictions, and betting tips\n\nSpain's 3-0 win over Croatia wasn't as easy or comfortable as the scoreline may indicate. In fact, many La Roja players were likely thanking goalkeeper Unai Simon in the locker room for bailing them out in the second half.\n\nThat's because Croatia registered 1.91 xG after the intermission, outshooting Spain 9-5 in the second half. Simon made three huge saves in the period and five on the day as he denied Croatia even a consolation tally.\n\nItaly's goalkeeper faced no such flurry in his side's 2-1 win over Albania. In fact, Opta says Gigi Donnarumma faced only one shot on goal the entire match.\n\nUnfortunately for him, it came 23 seconds into proceedings as the Azzurri fell behind to the fastest goal in Euro history. While he wasn't credited with a save, replays show he did deny what may have been a late equalizer when he blocked a stoppage-time shot off his side.\n\nBut when Spain rolls in on Thursday, the PSG keeper will be much more involved. Alvaro Morata's goal against Croatia put him second among all Spanish goalscorers at the Euros and moved him to third in the competition's all-time scoring list.\n\nHe will be flanked by Nico Williams and the dynamic youngster Lamine Yamal, who created three chances and had six touches in the box vs Croatia. They'll lead an attack that certainly will generate a higher mark than the 0.50 xG posted by Albania.\n\nBut at the other end, Simon's going to face a higher caliber of attacker as well. No offense to Ante Budimir or Andrej Kramaric, but the Italians will have more dangerous weapons leading their line. Gianluca Scamacca is in solid form and played well despite not scoring against Albania.\n\nNicolo Barella did find the back of the net and is always a threat from midfield, with goals in consecutive matches for the Azzurri. And both Lorenzo Pellegrini and Federico Chiesa are threats to create goals at any time.\n\nThis should be one of the matches of the Euro 2024 group stage, and this tournament has shown that goals are in abundance. Both defenses will be heavily tested, and I expect them both to crack at some point with the attacking talent on display. Look for both teams to score for the fourth straight meeting between these two proud footballing nations.\n\nSpain vs Italy same-game parlay (SGP)\n\nUnai Simon was tested heavily by the Croatian attack, and he came up with five critical saves on the day. He's faced Italy three times in competitive matches, making nine totals saves and at least two in each match.\n\nItaly has posted at least four shots on target in five of their last six competitive matches, and a total of 12 in their last three meetings with Spain. If Simon is locked in again, three saves here should easily be attainable.\n\nOne of the shots he'll face is likely to come off the boot of Nicolo Barella. When Italy counters, as they'll likely do here with Spain getting back to possessing more of the ball, he's often found charging into the box on late runs. But he's also a threat to shoot from midfield at any time, as he showed with his beautiful strike for the winning goal.\n\nBarella has attempted 11 shots in his last eight starts for Italy, with at least one shot in seven of those outings. giants eye last 16 in blockbuster clash", "body": "Spain and Italy will be targeting a place in the Euro 2024 knockout stage when they meet in a classic encounter.\n\nThe two sides got off to the perfect start in their competition openers, as Gli Azurri survived an early scare to beat Albania 2-1, while La Roja recorded an impressive 3-0 win over Croatia.\n\nAnother victory for either team would be enough for them to advance through to the round of 16 with a game to spare.\n\nSpain were knocked out of Euro 2020 by Italy in the semi-finals, who went on to win the tournament, and both teams will be keen to boost their hopes of glory this time around with a big result here.\n\nSpain vs Italy: Date and how to follow\n\nThe Group B showdown will take place on Thursday, June 20.\n\nKick-off at the Veltins-Arena in Gelsenkirchen will start at 8pm UK time.\n\ntalkSPORT will have full coverage of the match presented by Natalie Sawyer.\n\nCommentary comes from Alex Crook and former Newcastle United manager Alan Pardew.\n\nTo tune in to talkSPORT or talkSPORT 2 through the website, click HERE for the live stream.\n\nSpain captain Alvaro Morata has played down any injury concerns after he was withdrawn midway through the second-half of the Croatia match.\n\nMorata scored the game's opening goal, and reassured fans in his post-match press conference that he would be fit for the Italy clash.\n\nManchester City midfielder Rodri was also taken off prematurely in the tournament opener after appearing to struggle physically, but manager Luis de la Fuente revealed this was simply fatigue.\n\nCentre-back Aymeric Laporte missed the Croatia match due to a muscular issue and it remains to be seen whether he will return in time to challenge Nacho for a starting berth in defence.\n\nItaly's Nicolo Barella had reportedly been dealing with a hamstring injury heading into the Albania tie, but appeared to ease any fears by playing 92 minutes in midfield and netting the winning goal.\n\nElsewhere, Juventus midfielder Nicolo Fagioli was forced to sit out of the defending champions' opening game with a bruised fibula, but is believed to be in contention to return against Spain.\n\nSpain squad\n\nItaly squad\n\nSpain vs Italy: What has been said:\n\nItaly manager Luciano Spalletti has urged his side to find their cutting edge against Spain.\n\nHe said: \"We have to improve. We thought we were better than we were in certain situations.\n\n\"We need to be meaner. We are neat and tidy in building things up but we need to hurt the opposition.\n\n\"We thought we were brilliant at keeping possession, but that's something we need to do better.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Spain boss Luis de la Fuente has called for calm ahead of the clash, as he shared his delight at his side's win over Croatia.\n\nHe said: \"I am very happy for everyone who has worked so hard to get to this point. This group is ambitious and it is a huge family, so I'm delighted for everyone.\n\n\"But we must keep our feet on the ground. We've started well, which gives us a bit of security, but now we need to think about Italy.\"\n\nUnsure who to back? {"uri": "8187712588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "21:12:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T21:12:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T21:09:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.90min.com/spain-1-0-italy-player-ratings-20-6-2024", "title": "Spain 1-0 Italy: Player ratings as La Roja qualify for knockout stages", "body": "Spain dominated Italy / Chris Brunskill/Fantasista/GettyImages\n\nSpain booked their spot in the last 16 of Euro 2024 with a dominant 1-0 win over Italy on Thursday evening.\n\nDespite racking up an impressive amount of chances, it was an unfortunate own goal from Italy's Riccardo Calafiori that separated the two sides. The result means Spain are now guaranteed to top Group B after hammering Croatia in their opener.\n\nSpain finish up the group stages against Albania next Monday, with Italy taking on Croatia in their third and potentially final match of Euro 2024.\n\nIt took a little over a minute for Spain to deliver the first punch in the battle of two international giants. Nico Williams' delicious cross to the penalty spot picked out an unmarked Pedri and the Barcelona midfielder's header forced Gianluigi Donnarumma into a smart stop.\n\nSpain were guilty of squandering another glorious opportunity in the tenth minute as they sliced through the reigning European champions. Alvaro Morata was provider on this occasion with a devilish delivery to the far post, but Williams inexplicably sent his header wide from just six yards.\n\nLuis de la Fuente's side continued to bamboozle their opponents as the half wore on, playing almost exclusively inside Italy's final third. However, they couldn't make their advantage count, with Donnarumma standing tall to keep out testing efforts from Morata and Fabian Ruiz.\n\nDespite a dominant first half display in Gelsenkirchen, Spain were unable to find the all-important breakthrough. Their profligacy in the final third meant the match entered the second half finely poised, with Italy in need of significant improvements across the pitch.\n\nSpain continued to overrun Italy after the restart but were once again left ruing their wastefulness. Pedri, who should have opened the scoring early in the first half, was picked out by Marc Cucurella inside the penalty area, but the 21-year-old was unable to sort his feet out as he rifled wide from close range.\n\nHowever, it mattered little three minutes later as La Roja took the lead - even if it wasn't a Spanish name on the scoresheet. Morata's near-post flick was palmed out by Donnarumma, but the ball ricocheted off the leg of Calafiori and trundled into the back of the Italy net for the fifth own goal of the tournament.\n\nItaly showed few signs of netting an undeserved equaliser but with only a goal between the sides, Spain couldn't afford to take their foot off the gas. Williams did his best to establish a two-goal cushion but his powerful strike slammed the crossbar with 20 minutes remaining.\n\nHowever, despite not adding to their lead following several late openings for substitute Ayoze Perez, Spain did manage to hold on under minimal pressure from a disappointing Italy side.\n\nGK: Unai Simon - 6/10 - A passenger for the majority of the game, doing far more work with his feet than with his hands.\n\nRB: Dani Carvajal - 7/10 - Rarely threatened by Italy's wide players and enabled Cucurella to roam down the left flank by tucking in when required.\n\nCB: Robin Le Normand - 6/10 - Took a few blows to the head throughout but they didn't knock him off his stride. Booked for a late challenge on substitute Mattia Zaccagni.\n\nCB: Aymeric Laporte - 7/10 - Despite being an injury concern heading into the clash, the Al Nassr centre-back showed no signs of weakness. Dealt with Gianluca Scamacca effectively.\n\nLB: Marc Cucurella - 8/10 - Played like a man possessed, winning duel after duel up against the misfiring Federico Chiesa. Provided plenty of attacking support down the left-hand side too.\n\nCM: Pedri - 7/10 - Should have put Spain ahead in the early stages of both halves but finishing aside, it was a terrific display from the diminutive magician. Floated across midfield and was always in space as Spain carved open Italy's backline.\n\nCM: Rodri - 8/10 - Composed, elegant and unflappable. Exactly what we have come to expect from Rodri, with the only frustration being that he will miss the clash with Albania due to suspension - not that it matters anymore given Spain have topped Group B.\n\nCM: Fabian Ruiz - 8/10 - A graceful display from the Paris Saint-Germain midfielder, who often provided the key pass in the final third. His wand-like left foot orchestrated many of Spain's attacks.\n\nRW: Lamine Yamal - 8/10 - Yeah, this fella shouldn't be 16. Showcased his quick feet regularly with some neat tricks and flicks, almost curled a beauty beyond Donnarumma from 25 yards out and generally tortured Federico Dimarco on the right flank.\n\nST: Alvaro Morata - 7/10 - Knitted play together neatly when the ball turned over and his near-post header forced Spain's opener.\n\nLW: Nico Williams - 9/10 - Left Giovanni Di Lorenzo chasing shadows with an electric display in Gelsenkirchen. Terrorised the Napoli defender from start to finish and had the crowd purring every time he got his foot on the ball.\n\nSubs not used: Alex Remiro (GK), David Raya (GK), Alejandro Grimaldo, Daniel Vivian, Jesus Navas, Nacho Fernandez, Dani Olmo, Fermin Lopez, Martin Zubimendi, Joselu.\n\nLuis de la Fuente - 8/10 - A truly dominant display from Spain against a well-stacked Italy side. Bodes well for La Roja moving forward after convincing victories in their opening two games.\n\nGK: Gianluigi Donnarumma - 6/10 - Made some important saves to stop Spain from filling their boots. Perhaps could have done better with Spain's goal.\n\nRB: Giovanni Di Lorenzo - 3/10 - A chastening experience for the full-back as Williams drove at him relentlessly. Often had to resort to hauling the winger to the ground, or simply watching him sprint away.\n\nCB: Alessandro Bastoni - 6/10 - Made an important intervention to deny Williams during the first half and didn't put a foot wrong on elsewhere.\n\nCB: Riccardo Calafiori - 6/10 - A largely composed display from the young Bologna defender, who was extremely unfortunate to leave the field with an own goal to his name.\n\nLB: Federico Dimarco - 4/10 - Struggled to cope with Yamal's blistering speed and nimbleness, while failing to provide any danger in the Spain half.\n\nDM: Jorginho - 5/10 - Couldn't offer any control or security in Italy's midfield and was withdrawn for the more physical Bryan Cristante at half-time.\n\nRM: Federico Chiesa - 4/10 - Toothless when he received possession and had no joy up against Cucurella. Surrendered the ball far too easily when supplied by his teammates.\n\nCM: Davide Frattesi - 5/10 - Anonymous throughout a poor first half for Italy, barely managing a kick. Hooked at half-time by Luciano Spalletti.\n\nCM: Nicolo Barella - 6/10 - The best performer in an Italy midfield that was completely dominated by Spain's technicians. At least offered his teammates options when they tried to play out from the back.\n\nLM: Lorenzo Pellegrini - 5/10 - Apart from a few fouls, the Roma man couldn't influence proceedings and was sloppy on the left-hand side.\n\nST: Gianluca Scamacca - 5/10 - Completely isolated in the first half, touching the ball just 12 times. Things didn't improve after the break despite one clever turn on the halfway line.\n\nSUB: Bryan Cristante (46' for Jorginho) - 5/10 - Impressively booked within 20 seconds of coming on - the fastest of any substitute in Euros history.\n\nSUB: Andrea Cambiaso (46' for Frattesi) - 6/10 - Italy were a little better after his introduction, but that's more telling of their first-half display.\n\nSubs not used: Alex Meret (GK), Guglielmo Vicario (GK), Alessandro Buongiorno, Federico Gatti, Gianluca Mancini, Raoul Bellanova, Matteo Darmian, Michael Folorunsho, Nicolo Fagioli, Stephan El Shaarawy.\n\nLuciano Spalletti - 4/10 - He will be bitterly disappointed with his side, who simply couldn't match Spain on or off the ball. including a penalty shootout win over Spain.\n\nSpain's victory over Croatia on Saturday was the first time in 137 games that they did not complete as many passes as their opponent - a run stretching back to 2008.\n\nSpain's 3-0 defeat of Croatia was far more eye-catching than Italy's come-from-behind 2-1 victory over minnows Albania, but the scorelines do not tell the whole story of either match.\n\nSpain were impressive in attack, where they produced one of the most fluent displays of the first round of matches, but their defence offered up numerous chances to a wasteful Croatia side. Indeed, Croatia actually had a higher expected goal tally than Spain in that match.\n\nNor was Italy's narrow victory over Albania quite as nervy as it looks on paper. The Azzurri fell behind early thanks to a daft error - Federico Dimarco throwing the ball directly into the path of Albania's Nedim Bajrami - but from then on Italy utterly dominated and should have won by a more comfortable margin.\n\nBoth teams are in transition, with Spain adopting a far more direct approach and Italy adapting to a new head coach and moulding a new defence that bears little relation to the one who led them to Euro 2020 glory.\n\nBut, despite offering less control and allowing opponents more chances to hit them on the break, the Spanish look the more dangerous side and {"uri": "8187722938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "21:21:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T21:21:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T21:20:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/italy-spain-report-2-6415469-Jun2024/", "title": "Dominant Spain brush past Italy to reach Euro knockout stage", "body": "Riccardo Calafiori's own goal was the difference between the two sides at Gelsenkirchen. The 42\n\nSPAIN QUALIFIED FOR the last 16 of Euro 2024 with a match to spare after beating Italy 1-0 in a dominant display which ensured that La Roja would go through as Group B winners.\n\nRiccardo Calafiori's own goal nine minutes after half-time was the difference between the two sides at Gelsenkirchen.\n\nBut the slender margin of victory didn't reflect a statement performance from Spain who completely nullified Italy and should have had the game won by half-time, as they did in their opening round thumping of Croatia.\n\nNico Williams was the star for Spain as he ran Napoli right-back Giovanni Di Lorenzo ragged and supplied the cross from which the unfortunate Calafiori poked the winning goal into his own net.\n\nLuis de la Fuente's team have a perfect six points at the top of the group and take on Albania on Monday knowing that they are already in the knockout rounds and playing like potential champions.\n\nFor Italy Thursday's deserved defeat was a reality check as vibrant Spain peppered the brilliant Gianliugi Donnarumma's goal throughout the match while the Azzurri failed to have a single attempt on target.\n\nIt was a performance reminiscent of the Euro 2012 final between the two teams when Spain crushed Italy 4-0 in the last international hurrah for tiki-taka football.\n\nHowever all is not lost for Luciano Spalletti's team, who are second on three points, as a draw with Croatia on Monday will be enough to guarantee qualification behind Spain.\n\nSpain could have been ahead twice in the first 10 minutes but squandered two great headed chances.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLess than two minutes were on the clock when an unmarked Pedri nodded Williams' pinpoint cross straight at Donnarumma.\n\nAnd then Williams, who had a field day against Di Lorenzo, was the guilty party by somehow heading wide Alvaro Morata's superbly delivered, inswinging ball from the left flank.\n\nSpain were clearly on top as Italy struggled to get out of their half, Gianluca Scamacca toiling on his own up front with little support and wasting possession when it did come his way.\n\nDonnarumma had to be at his best twice within a matter of seconds when he first stuck out a foot to deny Morata and then pulled off a superb fingertip save which kept out Fabian Ruiz's powerful drive from distance.\n\nMeanwhile at the other end of the pitch Spain goalkeeper Unai Simon was a virtual spectator as Italy's sole shot in the first half came just before the break when Federico Chiesa blazed a poor effort over from a difficult position.\n\nThe same pattern of Spanish possession and Italian defending continued after half-time and Pedri again wasted a great chance in the 51st minute, slamming wide after Marc Cucurella pulled back a perfect low cross.\n\nBut Spain got the breakthrough soon after and it came through more sensational play from Williams on the left, who made mincemeat of Di Lorenzo before fizzing across a ball which Calafiori couldn't help but divert into his own goal.\n\nLa Roja went close to doubling their lead with two distance strikes from Morata and teen sensation Lamine Yamal, before the superb Williams smashed an effort past Donnarumma which came crashing out off the crossbar in the 71st minute.\n\nItaly pushed forward in hope of an equaliser after Mattia Zaccagni and Mateo Retegui replaced the ineffective Chiesa and Scamacca.\n\nBut in the dying moments Donnarumma again made two superb saves to twice stop Ayoze Perez making the scoreline better reflect a one-sided contest.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024\n\nWritten by AFP and originally published on The 42 whose award-winning team produces original content that you won't find anywhere else: on GAA, League of Ireland, women's sport and boxing, as well as our game-changing rugby coverage, all with an Irish eye. tasty clash", "body": "SPAIN face reigning European champions Italy in their second group game this week.\n\nThe two sides meet at Arena AufSchalke in Gelsenkirchen on Thursday.\n\nLa Furia Roja kicked off their Euro 2024 campaign with a convincing 3-0 win over Croatia at the weekend.\n\nFirst-half goals from Alvaro Morata, Fabian Ruiz and Dani Carvajal gave Luis de la Fuente's side the best possible start to the tournament.\n\nMeanwhile, Italy overcame an early scare to beat Albania in their opening match.\n\nNedim Bajrami came out of nowhere to score the fastest goal in European Championship history just 23 seconds into Saturday's match, but Alessandro Bastoni and Nicolo Barella responded by netting back-to-back goals in five minutes to seal the win.\n\nBoth teams will be eyeing the top spot in Group B ahead of the knockouts.\n\nAnd a win could see either side all-but guarantee qualification.\n\nBoth teams got off to a winning start in Germany at the weekend.\n\nSpain cruised to a 3-0 win over Croatia, while Italy clinched a 2-1 victory over Albania.\n\nThe Azzurri suffered quite the scare in their opening match after going 1-0 down within the opening minute, so they will have to up the performance levels on Thursday.\n\nAlvaro Morata was forced off in the latter stages of Spain's match against Croatia, but the striker has since insisted that he just suffered a knock.\n\nRodri was also withdrawn during the match due to fatigue.\n\nAymeric Laporte was not involved at the weekend due to a muscle issue and it remains to be seen whether or not he will return in time for the match against Italy.\n\nNicolo Fagioli will likely be in contention after missing the opening match due to a bruised fibula.\n\nAside from that, Italy have no significant injury concerns.\n\nLamine Yamal became the youngest footballer to play in a European Championship match when he started for Spain against Croatia.\n\nThe 16-year-old provided an exciting spark among the team and managed to set up Dani Carvajal's goal on the brink of half-time.\n\nAhead of Thursday's clash, Italy midfielder Davide Frattesi admitted Yamal is destined to become a \"top-class\" player.\n\nAs for Italy, Nicolo Barella is a threat.\n\nThe midfielder scored the winning goal for the Azzurri against Albania last week.\n\nAnd after the match he was likened to Kevin De Bruyne and Toni Kroos by former Italy Under-21s manager Luigi Di Biagio.\n\nHe told Gazzetta dello Sport: \"Barella has a different physicality, but he is a mix between the first version of Kevin De Bruyne, who used to play more in central midfield and the first version of Kroos, who made more late runs.\"\n\nFollowing his team's win over Croatia, Spain manager Luis de la Fuente said: \"We have the ability to continue to impose our style. We played very well with a high press, which allowed us to get the ball back.\n\n\"But one of the characteristics of Spain is our ability to change approaches and that variety is our strength. We have different qualities, different tactical approaches, and that's an extra difficulty for opponents.\n\n\"If you have players with the speed of Lamine [Yamal] or Nico [Williams] or Ferran [Torres], that gives you something else. And the players know that. I have always tried to communicate that.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Italy boss Luciano Spalletti wasn't best pleased with his team's performance against Albania.\n\nHe said: \"We saw many good things, but they need to actually take us somewhere, otherwise they are pointless.\n\n\"There was the possibility to hurt them several times and we didn't go for it. {"uri": "8185466090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:17:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:17:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:15:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/2024-06-19-spain-and-italy-set-to-extend-record-euro-rivalry/", "title": "Spain and Italy set to extend record Euro rivalry", "body": "Spain's Dani Carvajal celebrates scoring their third goal in their 3-0 Euro 2024 Group B win against Croatia at Berlin Olympiastadion on Saturday.\n\nImage: Reuters/Fabrizio Bensch\n\nWhen Italy and Spain meet in Gelsenkirchen on Thursday, they will write a new chapter in what has developed into the most intense head-to-head rivalry in European Championship history.\n\nNo two countries have met more often at Euro tournaments than the Azzurri and La Furia Roja -- the Red Fury -- who will line up against one another for the eighth time since 1960.\n\nIt will also be the fifth edition in a row that the two heavyweights have met head to head at a European Championship.\n\nThat remarkable run began in 2008, when eventual winners Spain beat Italy in a quarterfinal, and it actually spans six matches: they met twice in the 2012 tournament including the final that year, which was also won by Spain.\n\nOver much of the country's sporting history, Spain's fans looked enviously across the Mediterranean Sea as Italy racked up four World Cup titles and the Azzurri battled for European supremacy with the mighty Germans.\n\n\"The never-ending torrent of some the best centre halves in history always gave them the upper hand, a rock which Spain smashed into time and again,\" journalist Javier de Paz Fernandez wrote in El Confidencial, a Spanish news website.\n\nBut of the three Euro crowns won by the two countries over the last four tournaments, two have gone to Spain, underscoring their rise as a soccer superpower that also saw them crowned world champions in 2010.\n\nIn the most recent European Championship showdown, Italy defeated Spain in a nail-biting Euro 2020 semifinal that went to penalties at Wembley.\n\nFederico Chiesa curled a shot past Unai Simon before Alvaro Morata beat Gianluigi Donnarumma from close range to secure a 1-1 draw. Morata and Dani Olmo missed in the shoot-out, and the Azzurri advanced to the final, beating England also on spot kicks.\n\nIn a last-16 encounter in 2016, Italy were again victorious when defender Giorgio Chiellini scored from close range and Graziano Pelle volleyed home in the dying moments for a 2-0 win.\n\nBut in their most important meeting in all competitions, Spain triumphed in the final of Euro 2012 when Vicente del Bosque's all-conquering team thrashed Italy 4-0 in Kyiv.\n\nDavid Silva started the rout with an angled header from a Cesc Fabregas cross and Jordi Alba made it 2-0. Late goals by substitutes Fernando Torres and Juan Mata earned Spain what remains the biggest win in a European Championship final.\n\nThat Euro title was the second in a row won by Spain who were crowned world champions in between at the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.\n\nThe stakes will not be as high in Thursday's Group B game at the Arena AufSchalke. Spain and Italy both won their opening matches against Croatia and Albania respectively and look well placed to advance into the knockout rounds.\n\nBut if they finish first and second in the group, they could be on course for another meeting, this time in the final in Berlin on July 14.", "source": {"uri": "timeslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "Times LIVE"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8183475984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:18:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:18:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:17:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://sportslens.com/news/arsenal-star-jorginho-italy-spain/", "title": "Arsenal Ace Jorginho Reveals How Italy Plan To Beat Spain In Group B Meeting", "body": "Arsenal and Italy star Jorginho has discussed how his team are planning to beat Spain in their upcoming UEFA EURO 2024 Group B meeting. The defensive midfielder believes the Azzurri must play with intensity and focus on their strengths to get the better of Group B leaders La Roja.\n\nGroup B rivals Italy and Spain were both in action on Saturday (June 15), with the former taking on Albania and the latter locking horns with Croatia.\n\nAlbanian attacker Nedim Bajrami scored the fastest goal in the competition's history against Italy, firing his team in front just 23 seconds in. Luciano Spalletti's side, however, did not unravel after going behind so early in the game. They turned the game on its head in the following 15 minutes, courtesy of goals from Alessandro Bastoni and Nicolo Barella. Albania tried to come back into the game, but Italy shut shop to secure a 2-1 win.\n\nSpain, on the other hand, took Croatia to the cleaners in the first Group B fixture. They ran circles around Luka Modric and Co., claiming a comfortable 3-0 victory. Alvaro Morata, Fabian Ruiz, and Dani Carvajal all scored in the first half to put the game to bed.\n\nItaly and Spain are level on three points, but thanks to La Roja's superior goal difference, they are sitting at the top of the table.\n\nOn Thursday night (June 20), Italy and Spain will square off, knowing that the winner will cruise into the last 16 of the competition. Ahead of the game, Jorginho revealed the tactics his team would use to beat the two-time European champions. He told VivoAzzurro (via Football-Italia):\n\n\"We'll need high intensity.\n\n\"Both teams will want to keep possession, and we must base our performance on our strengths, not their weaknesses. The coach wants us to play good football and move the ball.\"\n\nThis will be Spain and Italy's second consecutive meeting in EUROs. They crossed paths in the semi-final of EURO 2020 -- a game Italy won on penalties.\n\nAfter Alvaro Morata missed his spot-kick for Spain, Jorginho took the decisive penalty for Italy. {"uri": "8187700140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:58:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:58:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:57:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5572867/2024/06/20/spain-italy-euro2024-result-analysis-yamal-williams/", "title": "The Briefing: Spain 1-0 Italy - Calafiori own goal settles 'European Clasico'", "body": "Meetings between Spain and Italy rarely disappoint and this one was no exception -- even if it was an own goal that settled the contest.\n\nSpain manager Luis de la Fuente described Thursday's Euro 2024 Group B match as a \"European Clasico\" in the build-up -- and his players certainly came out motivated to impress.\n\nThey dominated the first half totally and Italy only went in level at half-time thanks to several key saves from goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma.\n\nAfter the break, Spain's luck changed and they finally found the goal they'd been pushing for when Italy defender Riccardo Calafiori turned into his own net after Donnarumma palmed out an Alvaro Morata header.\n\nDefending champions Italy tried to respond, but in truth the margin of defeat might have been greater -- Athletic Bilbao winger Nico Williams' stunning curling strike from outside the box hit the bar with 20 minutes to play.\n\nVictory sees Spain progress to the knockout stage as group winners, while for Italy it's all to play for against Croatia on Monday.\n\nHere, The Athletic's Dermot Corrigan, Mark Carey and James Horncastle take us through the talking points of a pulsating encounter in Gelsenkirchen.\n\nThis was definitely the best that Spain have played since De la Fuente became national coach in December 2022, and arguably their best display since the Euro 2020 semi-final against Italy, or maybe even the Euro 2012 final, against Italy too.\n\nDe la Fuente's side went on the attack from the first whistle, mixing direct running wingers Williams and Lamine Yamal, with incisive passing from midfield trio Pedri, Rodri and Fabian Ruiz. Williams' dribbling especially was causing havoc every time he got on the ball, and everything seemed to be clicking perfectly for his team.\n\nSpain had nine shots -- four on target -- before Italy managed their first effort at goal, a wild effort from Enrico Chiesa just before the break.\n\nThe one-way traffic continued after half-time, and Spain got to 11 efforts at goal without finding the net. Persistence paid off though. when Williams once again drove at right-back Giovanni Di Lorenzo, and they deserved the good fortune which saw slight touches from both Morata and Donnarumma before Calafiori could not help but knock the ball into his own goal.\n\nThe Spanish fans in Gelsenkirchen were loving it, with 'Ole' cheers breaking around the stands. The only slight concern was having so many shots and only scoring once. But with qualification for the next round secured already, De La Fuente and his team were very satisfied with their night's work.\n\nDermot Corrigan\n\nSome will focus on Donnarumma palming Morata's header into a helpless Calafiori's path for Spain's goal. But Italy would have gone behind much earlier if it weren't for their skipper.\n\nAs the team in front of him were run ragged by Williams and Yamal, the 25-year-old kept things dignified. In stoppage time against Albania, his arm-pit denied Rey Manaj an equaliser. Donnarumma celebrated that save as if it were a goal. It clinched a curtain-raising win.\n\nOn Thursday he had far more to do. And but for the goal which Spain were long overdue looking at their expected goals, he offered a reminder why he was named player of the tournament three years ago when Italy were crowned champions.\n\nThe 25-year-old palmed Pedri's early header over the bar. He tipped Fabian's long-ranger behind for a corner and made sure Morata didn't beat him at his near post after Yamal left three Italy players in his wake. Shortly after going behind his strong wrist sent a Morata shot into the heavens.\n\nHis critics will seize on his part in Calafiori's own-goal as they did his uncertainty coming for crosses in PSG's Champions League tie with Barcelona. But without Donnarumma a confidence shaking defeat could have been a humiliating one.\n\nJames Horncastle\n\nThere were battles all over the pitch in Gelsenkirchen, but one particular clash that caught the eye in the first half was between Italy's Jorginho and Spain's Pedri.\n\nIt started in the opening two minutes, as Pedri ghosted into the box after peeling off Jorginho with a simple shimmy to get on the end of cross from Williams to head at goal -- a chance he arguably should have scored from.\n\nItaly initially set up with 4-4-2 structure out of possession, but Pedri was drifting beautifully into pockets of space between Italy's defensive and midfield lines, meaning the Italians switched to a 4-1-4-1 shape off the ball to account for the 21-year-old's runs.\n\nIt was Jorginho whose head was on the swivel, ensuring he was rarely far away he was from Spain's No 20. Pedri would often position himself in the blindspot of Jorginho and another simple shimmy in the first half saw him bear down on goal from a single pass played through midfield as he looked to create once more.\n\nIn return, Pedri would often stand on Jorginho when Italy were building out from the back, ensuring that Luciano Spalletti's side did not have an easy method of working the ball through the centre of the pitch.\n\nThe game of cat and mouse only lasted the opening 45 minutes as Jorginho was taken off at half-time, with Bryan Cristante brought on to provide more of a physical presence and Nicolo Barella dropping into a deeper role -- such was the danger that Pedri imposed upon Italy.\n\nMark Carey\n\nWilliams and Yamal are the two young exciting stars of this new-look Spanish team, and after Barcelona teenager Yamal made his mark against Croatia in the first game, tonight it was the Athletic Bilbao player's turn to shine.\n\nWilliams was into the action straight away, with a run and cross in the opening minutes which almost saw Pedri head Spain in front. Every time he picked up the ball, he went straight at his marker Di Lorenzo, often on the outside to cross, but sometimes cutting in to link with team-mates.\n\nItaly coach Spalletti's half-time changes were about trying to curb his influence, but it did not work. When Williams was double-marked, instead he played in left-back Marc Cucurella on the overlap, leading to another Spain chance.\n\nIt was fitting that yet another run and cross from Williams led to the opening goal, even if there was an element of fortune to how the ball ended up in the net. With a bit more luck he would have ended up on the scoresheet himself, with a first half header flying just wide, and a thumping 20-yard curler rebounding from the woodwork in the second half.\n\nIt was a startling display from the 21-year-old, and if he can keep this form up during the tournament his \u20ac50million release clause will look very tempting, especially to cash-rich Premier League clubs. More displays like this and Spain will also be serious contenders for this Euro trophy.\n\nDermot Corrigan\n\nMuch has been said about Spain's departure from their tiki-taka, death-by-passing approach of tournaments gone by, but when you have the directness and searing pace of Yamal and Williams on either flank, you can understand why.\n\nCompared with their previous major tournament in the 2022 World Cup, Spain offer so much more directness and purpose in their attack with their willingness to take on their man and commit bodies with trickery and skill.\n\nIt was on show again on Thursday evening, as Spain's 24 attempted take-ons against Italy were more than any other game in World Cup 2022 or Euro 2020. This largely consisted of Spain getting the ball wide and crossing into dangerous areas, as they have numerous opportunities to punish Italy via such means.\n\nIt was that method of attack that led to goal with Williams causing more chaos, driving to the byline and crossing dangerously as Italy panicked themselves into an own goal from Riccardo Calafiori.\n\nWilliam's 11 attempted take-ons were not just more than any other player on the night, but no player has registered more than the 21-year-old's tally in a single game in the tournament so far. Couple that with the fearlessness of Yamal on the opposite flank and the confidence of Pedri and Fabian Ruiz to drive forward in central areas, and this Spain side have evolved into a team of take-on titans.\n\nMark Carey\n\nIn the headline match-up in the 'group of death', Spain secured top spot and qualification for the knockouts with this 1-0 win.\n\nThe result leaves the Italians needing a draw against Croatia in their final game to be sure of advancing. A defeat would move Croatia above Italy on four points.\n\nAlbania would also move on to four points if they beat Spain. If Albania and Croatia both finish on four points -- as well as eliminating Italy -- they would have to be separated by overall goal difference in the group, having drawn 2-2 in their match against each other.\n\nThe other side may qualify as a best-placed third-place team.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Italy, meanwhile, had to come back from conceding the earliest goal in Euro history before gritting out the rest of the match with the slim advantage.\n\nSpain has won the last two between the two nations, but Italy triumphed on penalties in the Euro 2020 semifinals en route to the title. The Italians have not beaten Spain outright in regulation, however, since a 2-0 victory at Euro 2016, a run of five straight winless meetings.\n\nThere is, quite simply, a talent disparity between these two sides that should play out on the pitch throughout these 90 minutes. While Italy have a few players like Nicolo Barella who might sniff the Spain side, a combined XI between these two teams would be largely dominated by the favorites.\n\nThey also have the form entering this match, as Spain clobbered a quality Croatia team in their opener while Italy looked vulnerable when pressed by Albania. If Italy can manage to frustrate Spain into submission, and force Rodri into one of his trademark \"the best team didn't win today\" post-match rants, they might have a chance, but that's an uphill battle against this in-form team.\n\nThere's absolutely no reason to suggest this match will end with a deflated score, and the plus odds are a generous gift in today's betting landscape where overs are often devoid of value.\n\nFrom every angle this game looks like it will be full of goals. Starting with the favorites, Spain have scored a combined 13 goals in their last three games, unloading for five against each of their pre-tournament friendly opponents Northern Ireland and Andorra before putting three by a defensively sound Croatia.\n\nSure, Italy have not conceded many goals of late, but they've given up eight in their last four against this very opponent, including multiple goals in three of those. They were pressured hard by Albania in their opener and looked vulnerable, and they have not faced a truly quality attacking since since falling 3-1 to England in Euro qualifying last October.\n\nFinally, Euro 2024 has seen goals flying early and often, as only four of the first 10 matches in this competition have gone under 2.5 goals, a significant amount of overs hitting for international football, which can oftentimes be lacking for goals compared to the club level. Hammer this, it's a massive opportunity.\n\nFew players thrive at the European Championship like Alvaro Morata, who rose to third on the competition's all-time leading goal-scorers list by finding the net in the opener against Croatia, with now seven Euro goals in just 11 career games.\n\nMorata, 31, has bagged a goal in four of his last six Euro games, with that stretch including his team's only goal in the 1-1 draw against Italy in the Euro 2020 semifinals, before seeing his decisive penalty saved by Gianluigi Donnarumma in the eventual shootout.\n\nHe will be itching for revenge, especially after he saw an incredible seven efforts fail to find the back of the net the last time these two teams matched up in the Nations League semifinals, with three of those efforts on target but saved by his nemesis Donnarumma.\n\nThis premier Euro 2024 group stage match between Italy and Spain will be televised in the United States on FOX, which can be found streaming on Fubo who are offering a free trial for new users. Spain raced into a 3-0 lead against the 2022 World Cup semi-finalists on Saturday before keeping Zlatko Dalic's side at arm's length in the second period.\n\nLuis de la Fuente's side have evolved considerably from the all-conquering generation of 2008 to 2012, with the latest iteration of La Furia Roja combining technical wizardry with speed and directness in wide areas. Another big test now beckons in the form of the holders.\n\nExpectations weren't so grand for Italy heading into the tournament compared to three years ago and, while their victory over Albania was slender, Luciano Spalletti's fingerprints were all over the Azzurri's performance. The former Napoli boss is starting to build this Italian side in his image and Thursday's contest is bound to be a belter.\n\nSpain were so impressive on Saturday that De la Fuente could name an unchanged team for Thursday's clash against Italy. Victory would then allow the manager to rotate heavily on Matchday 3.\n\nLamine Yamal and Pedri's minutes must be smartly managed, especially given the latter's injury woes since his stellar Euro 2020 campaign.\n\nMarc Cucurella was preferred to Alejandro Grimaldo at left-back against Croatia. Aymeric Laporte is building up his fitness and could earn minutes off the bench.\n\nSpain predicted lineup vs Croatia (4-3-3): Simon; Carvajal, Nacho, Le Normand, Cucurella; Rodri, Pedri, Fabian; Yamal, Morata, Williams.\n\nThere's been speculation in the Italian media of Spalletti making several changes to his XI to mitigate Spain's threat in Gelsenkirchen.\n\nStrong man-marker Gianluca Mancini could come in for Bologna's Riccardo Calafiori at centre-back to duel Spain captain Alvaro Morata. The pair faced off on many occasions while Morata led Juventus' line.\n\nThe steely Bryan Cristante may replace Davide Frattesi or Lorenzo Pellegrini in midfield, while Gianluca Scamacca could drop to the bench in favour of the energetic Mateo Retegui.\n\nItaly predicted lineup vs Spain (4-3-3): Donnarumma; Di Lorenzo, Mancini, Bastoni, Dimarco; Jorginho, Cristante, Barella; Chiesa, Retegui, Pellegrini.\n\nSpain were so impressive against Croatia, but the signs were promising for Italy as well against a tricky Albania side. Thursday's bout has the potential to be the best of the group stages given the quality of both squads and respective styles of the two managers.\n\nSpain's collective cohesion will be tough for the Italians to slow down, although its within the Italians DNA to nullify attacking majesty. Mediterranean derby", "body": "Two heavyweights of European football step into the ring on Thursday as Spain and Italy aim to secure an early place in Euro 2024's knockout phase.\n\nBoth won their opening Group B fixture, so one more point should prove enough for the reigning champions and their Nations League nemesis to progress.\n\nWhen Spain coach Luis de la Fuente sent his team out at Berlin's Olympiastadion for their Euro 2024 opener, he could hardly have imagined they would return at halftime with a three-goal lead over Croatia.\n\nAlvaro Morata, Fabian Ruiz, and Dani Carvajal all scored before the break, kicking off the campaign with a resounding success.\n\nMorata reached double figures in major tournaments, while Carvajal became the oldest Spanish scorer at a Euro.\n\nFielding the tournament's youngest player, 16-year-old Lamine Yamal, who assisted the third goal, and seeing Unai Simon save a penalty, Spain's composed performance suggests they are strong contenders for the trophy this summer.\n\nWith European titles in 1964, 2008, and 2012, Spain aims for a fourth continental crown.\n\nThey have lost just one of 11 competitive games under de la Fuente, winning the last seven, their best run since 2017.\n\nRecent results against their next opponents in the \"Group of Death\" have been particularly positive.\n\nLa Roja defeated Italy in successive UEFA Nations League semifinals, winning last year's edition.\n\nHowever, they have never won three consecutive matches against their Italian rivals.\n\nWhen the two teams meet in Gelsenkirchen, a point apiece could see both through to the last 16, potentially allowing de la Fuente to rest key players against Albania.\n\nNonetheless, pride will be on the line.\n\nWhile their Iberian rivals have dominated recently, Italy famously overcame Spain on penalties three years ago en route to Euro 2020 glory.\n\nSince losing to La Roja in the Nations League last June, the rejuvenated Azzurri have suffered only one defeat in their last 12 matches, winning eight.\n\nUnder Luciano Spalletti's guidance, they have regained their vigor, recovering from a dip in form under Roberto Mancini.\n\nItaly began their title defense shakily but quickly bounced back in Saturday's Group B clash against Albania to secure maximum points.\n\nSassuolo's Nedim Bajrami set a new Euros record by scoring the fastest goal ever after just 23 seconds.\n\nHowever, Spalletti's team soon equalized through Alessandro Bastoni, and Nicolo Barella put them ahead.\n\nNow unbeaten in 10 European Championship matches, with their last defeat dating back to a 2-0 loss to Spain in 2016, Italy's most recent setback in the competition was eight years ago against the Republic of Ireland.\n\nThough considered outsiders this summer, the Azzurri aim to become only the second team to win consecutive Euros, following Spain.\n\nFirst, they must ensure progress to the knockout phase.\n\nEasing concerns about their fitness after last week's win over Croatia, both Rodri and Alvaro Morata participated in full training and will be available on Thursday, when Aymeric Laporte might return from injury.\n\nThe France-born defender missed Spain's opening match entirely but could now take a spot on the bench, with Nacho and Robin Le Normand likely continuing in the center of La Roja's back four.\n\nFew changes, if any, are expected in Luis de la Fuente's lineup, though Dani Olmo and Alex Grimaldo are strong candidates for promotion to the starting XI.\n\nMeanwhile, Italy can also field an unchanged side in Gelsenkirchen, as all their players were available for training after the victory over Albania.\n\nLuciano Spalletti has stated he isn't committed to a specific formation, but some personnel changes suggest a more cautious approach: Gianluca Mancini offers a more conservative center-back option compared to the forward-raiding Riccardo Calafiori; Bryan Cristante might replace Roma teammate Lorenzo Pellegrini to bolster the Azzurri's midfield.\n\nOne player certain to start is Nicolo Barella, who has five goal involvements in his last seven international appearances.\n\nHowever, Genoa striker Mateo Retegui is pushing to replace Gianluca Scamacca up front.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, "authors": "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/sport/soccer/2024-06-19-spain-and-italy-set-to-extend-record-euro-rivalry/", "title": "Spain and Italy set to extend record Euro rivalry", "body": "Dortmund -- When Italy and Spain meet in Gelsenkirchen on Thursday, they will write a new chapter in what has developed into the most intense head-to-head rivalry in European Championship history.\n\nNo two countries have met more often at Euro tournaments than the Azzurri and La Furia Roja -- the Red Fury -- who will line up against one another for the eighth time since 1960.\n\nIt will also be the fifth consecutive edition that the two heavyweights have met head-to-head at a European Championship.\n\nThat remarkable run began in 2008, when eventual winners Spain beat Italy in a quarterfinal, and it spans six matches: they met twice in the 2012 tournament including the final that year, which was also won by Spain.\n\nOver much of the country's sporting history, Spain's fans looked enviously across the Mediterranean Sea as Italy racked up four World Cup titles and the Azzurri battled for European supremacy with the mighty Germans.\n\n\"The never-ending torrent of some of the best centrehalves in history always gave them the upper hand, a rock which Spain smashed into time and again,\" journalist Javier de Paz Fernandez wrote in El Confidencial, a Spanish news website.\n\nBut of the three Euro crowns won by the two countries over the past four tournaments, two have gone to Spain, underscoring their rise as a soccer superpower that also saw them crowned world champions in 2010.\n\nIn the most recent European Championship showdown, Italy defeated Spain in a nail-biting Euro 2020 semifinal that went to penalties at Wembley.\n\nFederico Chiesa curled a shot past Unai Simon before Alvaro Morata beat Gianluigi Donnarumma from close range to secure a 1-1 draw. Morata and Dani Olmo missed in the shoot-out, and the Azzurri advanced to the final, beating England also on spot kicks.\n\nIn a last-16 encounter in 2016, Italy were again victorious when defender Giorgio Chiellini scored from close range and Graziano Pelle volleyed home in the dying moments for a 2-0 win.\n\nBut in their most important meeting in all competitions, Spain triumphed in the final of Euro 2012 when Vicente del Bosque's all-conquering team thrashed Italy 4-0 in Kyiv.\n\nDavid Silva started the rout with an angled header from a Cesc Fabregas cross and Jordi Alba made it 2-0. Late goals by substitutes Fernando Torres and Juan Mata earned Spain what remains the biggest win in a European Championship final.\n\nThat Euro title was the second consecutive won by Spain who were crowned world champions in between at the 2010 World Cup in SA.\n\nThe stakes will not be as high in Thursday's Group B game at the Arena AufSchalke. Spain and Italy both won their opening matches against Croatia and Albania respectively and look well placed to advance into the knockout rounds.\n\nBut if they finish first and second in the group, they could be on course for another meeting, this time in the final in Berlin on July 14.", "source": {"uri": "businesslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessLIVE"}, "authors": [], The Spanish were left incensed after being denied a penalty when an elbow from Mauro Tassotti on Luis Enrique was missed in injury time, as La Roja chased an equaliser.\n\nSpain were the dominant force in international football as the noughties became the 2010s, as La Roja won three consecutive major tournaments. The Spaniards' spellbinding brand of football saw them fail to concede a single knockout stage goal across the three tournaments and culminated in a 4-0 thrashing of Italy at Euro 2012.\n\nThe Azzurri had eliminated England and Germany en route to the final but were no match for Spain's pass masters in the decider. David Silva opened the scoring with a header and Jordi Alba doubled the lead before half-time.\n\nJuan Mata and Fernando Torres scored late goals for Spain who recorded the biggest winning margin in a European Championship final.\n\nSpain and Italy were drawn together in qualification for the 2018 World Cup and it was the Spanish who stormed to top spot. Italy were unbeaten in qualifiers for over a decade but were a sorry second-best at the Bernabeu.\n\nIsco scored twice for the hosts in a superb Spanish performance before substitute Alvaro Morata turned in a third from Sergio Ramos' cross after a breakaway late on.\n\nItaly were condemned to the playoffs and lost 1-0 to Sweden over two legs, missing out on the World Cup for the first time since 1958.\n\nSpain were beaten in a semi-final for the first time in their history after a shootout defeat to Italy at Euro 2020.\n\nRoberto Mancini's Italy team had entered the tournament on a long unbeaten run and stretched their run without defeat to 33 games to book a place in the final. Federico Chiesa's curler put the Azzurri in front at Wembley, but Alvaro Morata came off the bench to force extra-time with an equaliser for Spain.\n\nHowever, Morata went from hero to zero in the shootout. The Spanish striker missed his side's fourth kick, allowing Jorginho to step up and seal Italy's place in the decider.\n\nRead - Spain vs Italy - Combined XI ahead of Euro 2024 clash", "source":
